subject: Re: [junit] Experience with jdk1.4 assert keyword
msgSnippet: ... I never use asserts for debugging, unless I m dealing with a particularly complex algorythm. ... They are certainly bad if you use them to catch bugs in
messageBody:
> IMO more of a debugging feature than unit testing

I never use asserts for debugging, unless I'm dealing with a particularly
complex algorythm.

>and certainly NOT a way to enforce runtime checks.

They are certainly bad if you use them to catch bugs in production code
"before they happen" (example: testing for null in a place where you should
never get a null reference), in the same way that it's a bad idea to use
exceptions to control normal program flow. But they are a great way to
communicate your intentions (example: asserting that the integer parameter
of a method is greater than 0 communicates to the reader of the code your
assumptions about the way that the method should be used). IMHO, that's the
most important reason to use asserts.
